columns.text: In this problem, we will determine whether the company should proceed with the new system.

In order to determine whether the new system is better for the company, we will compare the cash available for the old system and the new system being proposed. We can recall that in order to get this, we must first solve for the cash available for $14$ days. This can be done by subtracting the cost per transaction from the average daily payment then multiplying it to the number of branches.

This will give us the cash available for the $14$-day investment:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash available}&=(\$207,000-\$175)\times 4\\[15 pt]
&=\$827,300
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the cash available for the 14-day investment is $\$827,300$

Now that we have this value, we can solve for the future value of the investment by multiplying this by the annuity factor. We can recall that the annuity factor we used in the previous problem is $14.012$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value of investment}&=\$827,300\times 14.012\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,592,127.60
\end{aligned}$$

The future value of this investment is $\$11,592,127.60$

Moreover, we can see from the problem that there will be a one-day delay in processing these payments. We can then take this into consideration by using this formula to get the value of the investment with the delay.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of investment with delay}&=\dfrac{\text{Future value}}{1+\text{Rate}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$11,592,127.60}{1+0.00013}\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,590,620.82
\end{aligned}$$

The value of the investment is now $\$11,590,620.82$

Now, we can compare the value of the investment for the two systems. We can do this by subtracting the value of the new system by the value of the old system. If the result is positive, then the new system should be adopted, if the result is negative, then the old system should be retained. 

We can recall that the value of the old system is given as $\$11,578,732.13$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference}&=\$11,590,620.82-\$11,578,732.13\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,888.69
\end{aligned}$$

Since the difference is positive, therefore, the new system should be adopted by the firm.

In this type of problem, we were able to compare the future value of two systems and determine which of those would be more beneficial to the company.

As we can see from the problem, there is a concept of a cost/value of delay which is evident in Step 5 where the delay was considered and the value of the investment dropped. 

Despite the delay, however, the new system still yielded a higher value compared to the old system which means that the new system is more beneficial to the firm.
